snippet: Most women with ovarian cancer, which kills 15,000 Americans a year,  miss out on treatments that could add a year or more to their lives, a study found.
abstract: Study presented at a meeting of the Society of Gynecologic Oncology in Los Angeles reports that most women with ovarian cancer receive inadequate care and miss out on treatments that could add a year or more to their lives; results highlight the widespread, persistent flaws in the care of women with the disease; specialists say a main reason for poor care is that most women are treated by doctors and hospitals that see few cases and lack expertise in the complex surgery and chemotherapy that can prolong life.
lead_paragraph: Most women with ovarian cancer, which kills 15,000 Americans a year,  miss out on treatments that could add a year or more to their lives, a study found.

headline.seo: Ovarian Cancer Study Finds Widespread Flaws in Treatment
headline.main: Widespread Flaws Found in Ovarian Cancer Treatment
headline.print_headline: Study Criticizes Care in Cancer Of the Ovaries
